talk.start.para: - Judging by the response to the Clerk's calling on of this Bill I am not the only honourable member who is glad to see the debate resumed. I am sure that I speak also for the departmental officers, who have been in the precincts of the House for a long time waiting for this debate to be resumed. However, I realise that the House does not always function along set lines.

speech.para: The amendments proposed by this Bill will make the Homes Savings Grant Act function more satisfactorily for many young Australians. When first introduced in 1964 this legislation was an example of progressive government. It gave young people the incentive to save, which is very important. The Government showed that it was prepared to help young people to the tune of $500 if they themselves were prepared to save. The amendments now before us follow the same progressive line of the original legislation. The Government has had time since 1964 to see how the Act has worked. Being a new idea, there were bound to be some faults in the practical application of the provisions of the legislation. Now, by this Bill, the Government is prepared to make sensible and practical alterations to the existing legislation.

I would like to pay a tribute to the Minister for Housing (Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin) for the magnificent work that she has done in handling her portfolio. I pay tribute also to officers of the Department of Housing. I know that they have played a leading part in framing the Bill that is now before us and I am sure that our appreciation goes out to them for the way they have performed their difficult task in administering the Act in the last three years and in getting their Department to function properly.

I want to talk about two provisions of the Bill. I intend to make my remarks very brief and I am sure that one honourable member will appreciate my doing so. That is the honourable member for Griffith (Mr Donald Cameron) who, I understand, is to make his maiden speech when I resume my seat. I hope that his folks back home are listening so that they will hear his effort. I come now to the two amendments on which I wish to comment. The first is contained in clause 11. It increases the value of the home that may attract a grant from $14,000 to $15,000. This is a realistic assessment of the situation. However, I have in mind the problems of people who build houses in the northern parts of Australia. The honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Calder) brought this matter to my notice, and I saw the position personally a couple of weeks ago when 1 visited Darwin. Houses in the northern parts of Australia cost very much more than those built in the more densely populated areas. Perhaps in the future the Minister could consider raising the limit for homes in the northern parts of Australia.

The second amendment that I wish to mention is contained in clause 13. This extends the period within which an application must be lodged from three months to twelve months and empowers the Department to accept applications lodged within such further periods as the Department in special circumstances allows. I have had a special interest in the people who have suffered because their applications have been lodged too late. I know that this amendment will mean the review of many hundreds of applications from young people who lodged them too late in the terms of the original Act. One of the major reasons for their leaving applications until they were too late was the advice they received, mainly from bank managers, that they had to be married before they could submit an application. Of course, this was not so, but many hundreds of young people suffered because of this misunderstanding.

I am particularly pleased to see that the Secretary of the Department will now have discretionary power to review these applications and in the future to treat late applications in the light of the circumstances that led to their being lodged after the time limit had expired. This will bring pleasure and satisfaction to many young couples. They were very disappointed to learn that they could not receive the grant. Many of them had worked very hard in their spare time at night and at weekends to build a house before they were married so that they could move in to their home shortly after their marriage. Thinking they had to be married before they applied for the grant, they put in their application only to find that they were too late. Some of these young couples felt that they were entitled to have their applications reviewed. I again pay a tribute to the attitude taken by the departmental officers and the Minister. The young people will now know that the Government is willing to look at the practical side of their problems and to take a common sense and understanding attitude.

I believe that this is a wonderful piece of legislation. It gives the young people the incentive to save for the basic objective of most Australians and that is to own their home. It is very good to see that the Government is willing to give these young people the incentive to save. It means a good deal to many young Australians and it will certainly help them to achieve their basic objective of owning their home. It gives me much pleasure to support the Bill.

talk.start.para: -I call the honourable member for Griffith and remind the House that this will be his maiden speech.

- It is with a deep sense of appreciation and an awareness of the privilege I enjoy as a member of the Parliament that I speak to the Bill. I acknowledge that the Standing Orders of the House require me to speak exclusively to the amendments contained in the Homes Savings Grant Bill. But, Sir, I trust that you will give me a degree of latitude on this occasion so that I may pay respects to my predecessor. It is a well merited, sincere tribute. Mr Bill Coutts reveals a quality that is admired by all Australians when reviewing an electoral effort. In short, I desire it to be recorded that the clean and fair manner in which he conducted his campaign at the last election leaves him, regardless of the people's decision on that day, still enriched with the thought that he went out with his integrity still intact. I also thank my friend, the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Kevin Cairns) who first persuaded me to nominate for the Griffith electorate and then helped me in my campaign.

speech.para: As a Queenslander, it is appropriate to mention my admiration for the Minister who has been given the responsibility of administering the portfolio of Housing. Her obvious dedication and love for her new position makes her an ideal choice to supervise this Department, which is of national importance. We of Queensland, irrespective of our political beliefs, are proud of our lady, Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin. The several discussions that I have had with her about this Bill have shown me that the Senator is keen to encourage as many as possible to take advantage of the scheme and to ensure the promotion of home ownership. The amendments contained in the Bill give me, a newcomer to this province, great heart as I see in it a realistic attitude in ironing out the problems and shortcomings that have become apparent during the time the scheme has been functioning. I hope that these periodic examinations will remain a normal exercise. This was part of the Government's policy speech for the 1966 election. It demonstrates the ability of the previous Minister to keep abreast of ever changing requirements and conditions. From all aspects, therefore, we can observe that this portfolio has been and remains in capable hands.

It may be appropriate to reflect upon the motives that led to this legislation being introduced three years ago. The first, and to my mind the most important, is that it encourages people to save towards buying their home. The Government has given true leadership in this direction and in some ways it is a pity that other economic factors, such as natural growth and higher average earnings, conceal the improvement in home ownership due to this incentive. I stress that it is an incentive. Secondly, the community as a whole benefits by reason of its being an instrument of national saving, thus making more money available for housing throughout the country. In fact, if we take the latest figure of $34,203,721 which has been paid out since the inception of the scheme and multiply it by three to establish savings held at the time of claim, we have $103m saved for this purpose, and this figure excludes all those who have not yet claimed and those who saved beyond the stipulated limit and period of time.

I again turn to the incentive aspect. Honourable members will observe how I have carefully avoided the use of the word assistance'. This is because the real purpose of this grant is an incentive, and whilst I applaud the amendments to the Bill I express the point that to maintain the high level of interest in the scheme it must be constantly reviewed and updated so that inflationary trends will not detract from the figure which was set with obvious Cabinet deliberation. It is quite factual, Mr Acting Speaker, that the $500 grant introduced in 1964 is calculated today to be worth $461. This is correctly assessed not on any increase in the cost of home construction but on the change in monetary values. I stress again the importance of not losing sight of the reason for the Bill's original introduction in 1964, and I look forward to witnessing many occasions when the incentive is correspondingly increased.

Perhaps the most pleasing aspect of this amendment is the atittude towards persons who have become widowed. Mr Acting Speaker, I trust that you will forgive me for what might appear a slight degree of inconsistency. I describe this alteration as a humanitarian approach occasioned by virtue of some individual's misfortune. The Minister told me of cases where people bad lost their lives about the day of the arrival of the payment. Under the old legislation, the hardship this had created for the surviving partner could only be described as unnecessarily tragic. The new provision contains the incentive aspect in its offer to a widowed person with a family, their being subjected to the same qualifying rules, to set their sights upon a home if they, at that point of time, do not already own one. In an insurance-minded community, it is not unrealistic to consider a reasonable percentage of people left in such circumstances receiving cash payments following the untimely death of a loved one. While I do not suggest for one moment that a house can replace the bread-winning husband and father, it can go a long way in restoring a sense of and actual security to a widow and her children. If this housing payment were to encourage only one in five widows in this category to plan on buying a home for her family, it would have achieved a lot. If it keeps alight the flame of independence and hope for the future, thus repelling despair and dispelling fear, it will be even more worth while.

I am fully aware, Sir, that a house need not necessarily be a home, but as English essayist Sydney Smith observed in 1843: A comfortable house is a great source of happiness, health and good conscience'. The truth of this statement stands today and can never be sincerely questioned. Australia has already the best record of home ownership in the world. I believe that the Homes Savings Grant Act is playing a significant role in improving the situation even more, and I welcome these amendments. Our social pattern of life is so closely interwoven with our home that in my mind this aspect warrants more than just a passing moment of the time allotted to me in this, my maiden speech. Incidentally, Mr Acting Speaker, another English writer, Wintrop Mackworth Preed. once wrote: 'Forgotten, like a maiden speech which all men praise - but none remember'. I certainly hope that this, my occasion, will not be a case in point.

Our social pattern of life is more closely aligned to political doctrines than many would care to admit. A major difference in basic philosophy between liberalism and socialism is that under liberalism we believe that the state is there to serve the people by providing leadership, where necessary, and ensuring that the individual is given an equal chance to take best advantage and develop the opportunities offering. On the other hand, Labor's socialist philosophy subscribes to the theory that society is at its best when the individual is working in the interest of the state which, through overall control, develops and provides. I have no intention or arguing the pros and cons of each case. I mention it only so that I can show clearly that there is little room for half way measures when it comes to encouraging home ownership in the Australian society. I am of the firm belief that in our community there is a greater incidence of vandalism and greater evidence of anti-social activity among those persons who do not have a tangible stake in the country than among those who, for instance, live in the environment of their own home. I fully realise that the Australian Labor Party has been out of office for the last eighteen years and that in fact the Australian people have entrusted it with the reins of government for only nine years out of the last half century. But it is obvious that one cannot reasonably expect full and complete home ownership in our society, especially with the upsurge in migration. However, we must never let up in our endeavours to improve the percentage. We must never content ourselves with the fact that already we have attained the highest rate of home ownership in the world.

There are a number of older people today living in state-owned Housing Commission homes and others renting privately-owned dwellings who received setbacks early in life. If they had been offered the opportunities that are available today, most would cer tainly be in a better position. There is a percentage of people affected in the depression of the 1930s, as there are some among the group who protected this country during the Second World War, who have never surmounted the setbacks of those times. Then there is the small group who have no desire to buy a home, and whilst I believe that this group, comprising for instance seasonal workers, is diminishing from generation to generation, it will always be there. However, there is little to be gained from dwelling on the past, and I mention it only that we might keep this issue in perspective. Unfortunately there is an attitude which, much to the shame of some supposedly responsible people, has been fostered politically. They have contended that there are two groups of people in our society - the haves' and the 'have nots'. This has been cultivated to the extent that many of the have nots* resent and loathe the 'haves* instead of trying to better their own position. How often do we hear the statement, said with bitterness: 'The Smiths own a new car' or 'The Joneses own their own home*. This, Mr Acting Speaker, unfortunately reacts in many cases upon the children and we see examples of vandalism perpetrated solely and wholly because of home environment which has taught that resentment of those who have been perhaps more fortunate and/or diligent is the pattern of life.

I realise that in many countries the State provides housing almost in its entirety, and whilst I do not propose to debate the' type of housing provided I mention that it is alleged that social misbehaviour is non-existent. However, in Australia we have seen the rejection of socialist policies since the I940's, and I believe this in itself places the responsibility on the shoulders of this Government to ensure that home ownership is the target for as many of our people as possible. There is little room for half measures. I therefore propose to plead the case of the persons who up to their mid-thirties or later had held the opinion that they were not the marrying type. For the information of the House, I delved into this question and found that, in 1964. 76.5L7 bridegrooms, which represents 89% of all bridegrooms in that year, and 78,926 brides, or 91.8%, were under thirty-six years of age at marriage. Hence, much less than 10% of all marriages take place where both partners are beyond the qualifying age of the Act, and whilst I recognise that the legislation is designed to encourage young people, perhaps the Minister could give consideration to extending the terms of the Act to ensure that the children of these marriages are given every opportunity to grow in the environment of their own homes. This should not lead to any difficulties in ascertaining who was eligible, because it would apply to first marriage. So that the purpose of encouraging the under thirtysix year olds to obtain their own homes as soon as possible is not negated, I would suggest one qualification for the over thirtysix year old couple and that would be the condition that to be eligible for the grant they must have commenced their home project within a stipulated number of years following marriage. To date, over 76,000 couples have taken advantage of our scheme, their average home account savings being S 1,345, drawing an average $448 incentive payment out of a possible $500. These figures reflect the high measure of economic success of the scheme and I think the dividend paid back to the community in the long term would justify an extension of eligibility.

One point which may be of interest to the House is that on a State basis, in Victoria and New South Wales, the States with the highest average earnings, compared to Western Australia and Tasmania, the lowest average earning States, the difference in submitted savings over the three-year period is less than $100. When we consider this in the light of variations of average incomes in the individual States, it is proof that the under thirty-six year old group shares the same degree of interest and determination towards home ownership irrespective of the opportunities to earn.

I mentioned earlier how migration affects our housing programme but I wish to make it clear that I consider the difficulties imposed are more than compensated by the growth this country is experiencing as a result of immigration. To diverge for a moment, I wish to pay tribute to the retired Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Calwell). To him I, as a young Australian, say: 'Thank you', and acknowledge the part he played in bringing into being the highly successful immigration scheme. Many things done by people in high office can be judged only by history but already there is evidence that today the younger people of our country, irrespective of their disagreement with Labor's and the honourable member's policies, recognise with appreciation the benefits accruing to us all as a result of his earlier efforts. He has helped to give us this advantage. It is up to my generation to preserve and strengthen it.

I now draw the House's attention to an advertisement in the English overseas Daily Mirror and Sunday Mirror' dated 11th August 1965. The advertisement told of how a person could be 'repatriated' back to the United Kingdom for £15 Sterling adults and £8 Sterling children, with up to two years to pay the balance. I fully subscribe to the theory that it is best for discontented migrants to return home. I recognise that some go back because of compelling compassionate circumstances involving sickness or death; others because they are unable to integrate in the new environment; and still others come on the basis of trial migration - if they prosper, they will stay: if they do not, they will return. The offer in the advertisement I have spoken of must certainly make it tempting to those who are not certain whether they like our country or not. I dare say many regret their having taken advantage of the travel now pay later scheme. A survey conducted by Dr R. T. Appleyard of the Australian National University, published In 1962, amongst migrants who had returned home, revealed that 71% of those who responded had either returned to Australia or wished to do so, and a further 11% were undecided.

Whilst I am ever mindful of the plight of the young married couple and Australian born citizen, the make-up of my electorate of Griffith, comprising nineteen Brisbane suburbs on the south side of the river, is such that one cannot help but be conscious of the changing pattern of the Australian population. I know many of the newcomers personally and have come to understand their problems, hopes and aspirations. I have shared also their disappointments. I resent this travel company capitalising upon those who have confused the pains of readjustment with discontent. We must foster in our migrants, from the day of their arrival, the thought of buying a home. I suggest to the Minister that we give to English-speaking migrants the booklet covering the scheme, and to the nev English-speaking migrants a precis of the scheme in their own tongue, inviting them to make inquiries. Even if they do not become eligible for some years, if they start planning and saving for the future there is a greater chance of their staying. We can never do too much to hold what we have acquired.

To conclude, I wish again to mark the importance of retaining the value of the incentive, the significance of bringing up the citizens of tomorrow in the environment of their own home and the role of migration in building a bigger and better Australia. There are many points raised by previous speakers that I have let pass without comment. Do not take this as an indication of lack of interest' on my part in their proposals, but rather as an acknowledgment that if one feels he has something worth while to contribute, sometimes there is little to be gained from repetition. I thank all honourable members for their attentiveness and finish with the fervent hope that my constituents will be as pleased with my initial effort as I am with the fact I did not collapse from nervous exhaustion. I support the Bill.

talk.start.para: - I take this opportunity of extending my congratulations to the honourable member for Griffith (Mr Donald Cameron) on the capable way in which he delivered his maiden speech. This is an ordeal that all members must contend with, but the honourable member for Griffith had my sympathy because he was subjected to a further ordeal - he has had to wait since 3 p.m. to make his speech. I thank the honourable member for the sentiments he expressed about his predecessor who was a personal friend of mine, and I know that he would be most pleased with the honourable member's statements. I also thank the honourable member for Griffith for the fine tribute he paid to my former Leader, the Honourable Arthur Calwell.

speech.para: It always amazes me when members opposite discuss this legislation to note how they eulogise themselves and so successfully mesmerise each other into believing they are helping young people to secure their own homes. They completely overlook the steep increase in the cost of purchasing a home since July 1964 when the homes savings grant scheme was launched. Today the great majority of young people have not the financial means to enter into a contract to purchase their own homes. I support the Bill in accordance with the decision of my Party although I must say that I do so with misgiving. This is the second time since the legislation was placed on the Statute Book in the autumn session of 1964 that it has been amended.

The size of the explanatory memorandum made available by. the Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr Bury) on this occasion indicates what little thought the Government gave to the initial preparation of the original legislation. Members on this side of the House then accused the Government of not giving real financial assistance to young people who desperately wanted their own homes but rather of continuing the spiral of costs which would deprive many young couples of obtaining their own homes. I criticised the Government and said that the scheme was a political gimmick used by the previous Prime Minister deliberately to attract support from young people for Government candidates. This action was repeated by the present Prime Minister (Mr Harold Holt) during the last election campaign when, to secure additional votes, he announced the Government's intention to drastically amend the legislation to erase many of the anomalies and injustices that had deprived many young couples of the opportunity of obtaining the grant.

In his second reading speech the Minister for Labour and National Service, representing the Minister for Housing, outlined that already 74,000 young couples have received homes savings grants totalling more than $3 3m to assist them to own and establish a home. I am grateful to the Minister for marking those figures available. They have enabled me to do some homework and to discover exactly how the scheme has been progressing, particularly during the last twelve months, and to understand what motivated the Government to bring in so many amendments to the Act. The amendments absolutely distort the original legislation. I refer honourable members to the second annual report of the Secretary of the Department of Housing. This report is for the year 1965-66. I remind honourable members that the year 1966-67 has only eight weeks to run. In another eight weeks we will have come to the end of this financial year.

If we look at the second annual report by the Secretary of the Department of Housing we find that from the inception of the scheme until 30th November 1966 there had been 57,726 grants to the value of $24,857,930. This is very interesting because if we compare these figures with those given by the Minister in his second reading speech, bearing in mind still that there is only eight weeks until the end of the financial year, we find that the grants made this year total only $8m. Although 29,647 young couples received grants in the previous year, this year only 19,000 grants will be made. It is quite evident to me what has motivated the Government to bring in so many amendments to the legislation. When we see how steeply the price of land has risen we can understand the Government increasing the limit on the value of the home from $14,000 to $15,000. But this increase of $1,000 is only a drop in the ocean when compared with increased prices which we have witnessed during the last twelve months, particularly in the Australian Capital Territory. That increase of $1,000 will not be of much assistance to young couples in the Australian Capital Territory because the average cost of a dwelling house and land during the last year has risen by about $1,500. All that the increase in the limit will achieve is to enable them to meet some of the increase in costs.

I was most surprised to hear on the radio advertisements by land sharks who are operating in this area. I come to Canberra only while the Parliament is sitting and I very seldom have an opportunity to listen to the radio while I am here. But recently while at the Kurrajong Hotel with my wife I listened to the 'Country and Western Hour'. This programme, which lasts for an hour, is sponsored by the Austral Development Co. which is presenting a very attractive picture of an area at the coast known as Surfside Beach. I understand the area is some short distance from Bateman's Bay. The gimmick offered on the programme was that everybody who was prepared to pay £750 - not dollars - for a block of land at Surfside Beach would be given another block by this very generous company. It became quite evident to me that if a person was prepared to be sucked in to pay £750, he had the opportunity to sell one block to another sucker and would get his own block free. This is going on in the Australian Capital Territory and there is not a shadow of doubt that ft has been going on in the States to an equal degree. It is no wonder that the Government is raising the limit on the value of the home that can attract the grant. In the course of the radio programme a very catchy tune was sung by Tex Morton. It told of the country boy coming to town and being met by the city slicker who immediately brought out the thimble and pea and attempted to take all the country boy's money. But strange as it mary seem, the country boy outwitted the city slicker and finished up taking all his money. I think it was an apt theme for the kind of land deal which this company was engaged upon.

I propose now to touch upon a matter which I took up with the Minister. This matter affects one of my constituents. I received a notification from the Minister informing me that the Homes Savings Grant Act does not permit the payment of the grant unless the Secretary is satisfied that the value of the home does not exceed $14,000. The case which I forwarded to the Minister related to a young architect who is engaged in the building trade in South Australia. He has technical knowledge of the trade and was able to go ahead, arrange for sub-contractors and build his own home. The total cost of his home, including the land, was about $13,000. This information was made available to the Minister, together with a complete list of receipts showing the actual cost of the project. Admittedly this young man was able to obtain the materials for about $800 less than the normal cost. The regional director in South Australia assessed the value of the home at more than $14,000. When the matter was brought to the attention of the Minister she said that she could not do anything because she was not permitted to make a grant where the value of the house was more than $14,000.

What I am particularly concerned about is that throughout the Act there is provision for the Secretary to appoint his regional directors to make assessments of house values and administer the State branch of the Department. The formula upon which the regional directors administer the Department is laid down so that there is no shadow of doubt. After an assessment has been made by the regional director the only appeal against the assessment lies to the Secretary of the Department. In my view this is appealing from Caesar to Caesar. I hope that the Minister can give some consideration to setting up some tribunal in each of the States to which young couples can go if they believe that they have grounds for appeal. They should not have to go before the Secretary who, in effect, makes the rules and administers them. I would appreciate it if the Minister would take note of my suggestion as probably there are many young couples throughout Australia who are in the same situation as the young architect to whom I have referred. They should have the right to have their appeal heard by an independent tribunal. I think they would be much happier, even if they were not successful in receiving the grant. Like the honourable member for Indi (Mr Holten) I am being brief so as to make up some of the time which we have lost since this afternoon.

One of my constituents applied for this grant but, because her period of saving was approximately two months short, the application was rejected. She had pointed out in her application that for three years prior to this she had been helping her father, who had an overdraft on his market garden, by giving him SIO a week. This result surprised me, because in another case I knew that the Department had accepted statutory declarations that people had lent money to their relatives. Provided the people were prepared to sign statutory declarations, the Minister was prepared to give them a grant. I was surprised by this refusal, as it was a genuine case. I understand that the numerous amendments to the legislation proposed by this Bill will probably cover my constituent.

I am never overjoyed, as honourable members opposite are, when this sort of legislation comes before us, because it has become evident to me that the only people benefiting from the steep increases in the cost of land and materials are the land sharks. They are having a Roman holiday. I hope that at some time in the future the Government will face up to the real position. The only way in which we can assist the many young couples, the workers, who have not sufficiently large sums of finance to enable them to benefit from this scheme, is by restricting land sharks and particularly by controlling the prices of building materials. I support the Bill, but I do so with some misgivings.

Mr DOBIE(Hughes) [10.131-1 congratulate the honourable member for Griffith (Mr Donald Cameron) on his fine maiden speech. Queensland is indeed fortunate to have a new member of his calibre. However, I question his point about the non-marrying types, as I know of no such persons. The Bill before the House deserves the support of all honourable members and most certainly demands the attention of every member who has an interest in and a concern about the housing problems which face those people who are seeking to establish their first home. There can bc no doubt that the homes savings grant scheme has been successful. More than $33m has been given to approximately 150,000 young people since its inception three years ago. This testifies clearly to the fact that it has been a success.

The scheme has certainly measured up to this Government's anticipations and has dispelled the criticisms that early came from the other side of the House that it would not get off the ground or attract the attention of young married people and those about to get married. The scheme is certainly soundly based and represents an integral part of the total approach to housing followed by this Government. The result of the Government's policy can be seen from the annual completion rate for new houses each year. Figures issued by the Commonwealth Bureau of Census and Statistics show that in 1948-49, which was the last complete year when the present Opposition was in office, 51,339 new houses were completed. In 1965-66, the figure was 81,096. It should be noted that in the past seven years the total completions has been in excess of 80,000 for five of those years.

I am delighted to see that the amendments being placed before the House widen and amend conditions of eligibility. From my experience as a bank manager I know that this evidence of good faith by the Government will be cordially received and will provide further encouragement for young people to save towards a home. Whereas the $500 grant does represent a real contribution to young people being able to find the necessary deposit, its most important aspect has been the dramatic way in which it has focussed the savings habit towards a home among people whose savings might otherwise have been directed towards something of a less fundamental nature. I am sure that this aspect of the legislation must be of special interest to the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Peters), who some three weeks ago showed his regard for the need to divert the direction of spending from consumer spending to the more essential aspect of building houses.

I do not intend to describe any of the specific amendments contained in this Bill, as other speakers have done so and others will follow. I am concerned that the matter of cost versus value has not been resolved to my satisfaction. The increased value of $15,000 would not cover many homes which are being purchased by people who would otherwise be eligible. For most of the young marrieds this figure, whether it be value or cost, seems to be fair. But for those people still under the age of thirty-six years who have saved and waited, the $15,000 cut off point is a little low, and I commend to the Minister that some discretion should be allowed in relation to houses in excess of this figure. After all, the cost and value of homes vary between States and areas, and an eminently fair figure for most of Australia may need to be adjustable for the higher cost in, say, Melbourne.

At this point I support some of the concern felt by honourable members opposite regarding the cost of land; but I remind them that there can be no doubt that in the main there is better value for money than there was, say, ten years ago, when developers were not expected to provide the number of services they provide today. When comparisons of land costs over this period are made, too often the costs of providing essential services are left out of the base figure. Although I do not intend to occupy the time of the House in describing the components of real value, I repeat that this hidden cost of services now included in land prices is significant. The point to be taken is that it is now easier for young people to buy their own homes at or soon after marriage than it has ever been. From my observations and study in other countries, I know that there is a greater incentive as well as a greater ability to do this in Australia than there is in any other country, despite what has been alleged by the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Connor) with regard to the United States of America. I was interested in the report of the Director of the War Service Homes Division. Referring to this report, the honourable member said:

quote.para: A report of the Director of the War Service Homes Division is most interesting ... in the two years since the introduction of the legislation the average cost of a dwelling house and home has increased by . . . New South Wales $1,026.

speech.para: I refer to an equally authoritative source - the report of the New South Wales Housing Commission for 1965-66 - which states on page 29:

quote.para: This year, despite the fact that recorded increases in basic construction costs showed a slight upward trend, there was no further increase in the average of prices tendered by builders in the Sydney area. There was in fact a slight reduction in the average of prices in comparison with last year.

talk.start.para: - But the Housing Commission does not buy land at estate agents' prices.
- I am speaking about the cost of housing. The report continues:

quote.para: General stability was maintained in cottage prices in most country towns.

speech.para: The development of the housing loan insurance scheme has been of great importance in this regard. Neither that scheme nor the homes savings grant scheme can be considered in isolation of each other. One has the effect of encouraging lending institutions to lend a greater percentage of their valuation to a prospective borrower while the other encourages that prospective borrower to save towards the necessary deposit. Both are proving successful, though I must admit I am surprised to see the hesitation with which the savings and trading banks and the insurance companies are approaching the insurance scheme. I hope that in the near future there will be an increase in the amount of business they put towards the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation.

Admittedly there have been certain legal problems in this regard but I understand that only one third of the first $1Om of business written came from the banks which would provide finance for a figure of well below SOO houses.

In mentioning the troubles that people have in saving towards their deposit for a home and in finding the right institution to lend them money, the cold hard fact cannot be forgotten that there are many young people who do not have the capacity to repay housing loans. This inability does not relate to interest rates, as is often suggested, but rather to the size of financial commitments which these young people undertake. It is not easy for anyone to be paying off say, a new Ford Falcon at the same time as a new home, irrespective of whether a sufficient deposit has been saved and finance for a home is available.

It is in the province of directing the savings habit towards homes savings that the homes savings grant scheme serves its most permanent purpose. I believe that young people have been alerted to the need for specific saving, particularly since 1964. From my own experience I know that there is a diminishing tendency for young couples to go for a new car when the choice lies between a house or that car. As many honourable members will be aware, the the housing development in my electorate is impressive. Equally impressive has been the proportion of young married people starting life together in their own homes. My experience throughout the St George and Sutherland districts in the southern area of Sydney confirms what I have already said about young people having been alerted to the home savings habit.

I mentioned in my maiden speech that I am concerned about the general lack of knowledge of the available sources of housing finance. Again I stress to the Minister for Housing the practical need for housing information bureaux, sponsored by the Department of Housing and supported by the life assurance companies, the trading banks, the savings banks, the building societies and mortgage management companies. Because of the changing policies of these various lending institutions, which have arisen and will arise out of the operations of the Housing Loans Insurance

Corporation, there is a need for an easily accessible information centre in each of the capital and provincial cities. Such a form of co-operation would not be new among the trading banks which have managed to service international airports on a rotating basis with great success and have provided a great service to the travelling public. So it could be for those folk requiring information about housing finance generally and, in particular, information about eligibility for home savings grants and loans which can be insured under the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation.

These bureaux need not be costly. With a minimal office staff provided by the Department of Housing and a rotating staff from the various lending institutions, no great burden would be placed on any one organisation or the department. Yet these bureaux would fill many gaps that now exist. As I mentioned before in this House, one may not always expect a bank manager to give full information about other lending institutions and vice versa. From my own experience in the field of housing loans, very few applicants for bank loans are aware of the requirements of the other institutions. How much better it would be for prospective home buyers to be able to call in for information at an office in, say, George Street in Sydney, Flinders Street in Melbourne, Queen Street in Brisbane, or similar sites in other cities. In cases where information beyond that furnished in publications was required they would be able to have a discussion with an informed officer. The scheme Ls practical, would not be costly, and would provide yet another service on the part of this Government for the young hard working members of the community.

Following the suggestion of my friend and colleague, the honourable member for Swan (Mr Cleaver), I hope that the Treasurer (Mr McMahon) will see his way clear to allow an income tax concession on interest accruing on deposits with permanent building societies. I agree that the subsequent movement of funds to such societies concerned with providing building finance will play a great part in resolving the problems surrounding the availability of housing finance, particularly for those people who are eligible for the homes savings grant.

When considered in conjunction with the growing importance of the Corporation - which is now writing business at the rate of $25m annually - the homes savings grant scheme is causing the sure and steady extermination of those parasitic money lenders of whom I had knowledge during my bank experience. At one time they charged interest rates as high as 20% to those people who felt the urgent need to buy their own homes, often sought money because of circumstances born of misfortune or ignorance of the facts as they applied to home lending. The passing of these risk-taking sharks is of no regret to any honourable member and has been of inestimable advantage to the young home buyers of Australia. We should remember that this clean-up is being brought about by the actions of this Government in its intelligent approach to housing in this country.

Despite the prophecies of doom that came from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in .1964 and 1965, the homes savings grant scheme has been successful. One only has to ask any of the 150,000 people who have already benefited by it. I am certain that the modifications and amendments included in the Bill will have the unanimous support of the people it mostly concerns - the solid, hard working young people who are the backbone of our prospering and progressive country. I wholeheartedly support the Bill.

Mr PETTITT(Hume) [10.27J - I too would like to congratulate the honourable member for Griffith (Mr Donald Cameron) on the excellent speech he made tonight. Unquestionably Queensland is being well served by its new members. Obviously they are able and practicable men and I am sure that Queensland people can look forward to more progress in the future than they have perhaps enjoyed in the past. I want to refer only briefly and directly to this Homes Savings Grant Bill. Without doubt the homes savings grant scheme has been a tremendous success. I think all honourable members will agree that this is so. There has been something of a sour grapes attitude by honourable members of the Opposition. They are not prepared to admit that it has been a tremendous success. Perhaps they are still living the days of the wartime Labor Minister, Mr Dedman, who said then that we did not want to build a race of little capitalists by encouraging everybody to own their home. That was Mr Dedman's mistake because the average Australian does want to own his own home. This is indicated by the high and still increasing rate of home ownership in Australia. The Government's purpose in introducing the scheme was to encourage more and more young people io save in order to have their own homes.

When the original legislation was introduced the then Minister for Housing said that as the scheme was new there would be anomalies. The Government gave an undertaking that it would do its best to iron out any anomalies, and that is why this Bill is before us now. Tt will correct many of the anomalies that have become apparent. Perhaps one of the most significant matters dealt within this Bill concerns a person who is widowed before the payment of a grant. Surely this is one of the most humane and necessary amendments. The raising of the limit of the capital value of the home for which grants may be paid has been necessitated by rising costs. I doubt whether the figure will be high enough even now, but this is a step in the right direction.

I appreciate very much the provision to make grants available to people who missed out, perhaps through a misunderstanding or because the builder took longer to complete the home; perhaps because they forgot the significant date or because certain people, including bank managers, did not understand the legislation. I can give many examples in my electorate and I am sure that other honourable members can do likewise.

Extension from three months to twelve months of the time limit for lodgment of applications will increase the opportunities of applicants. There are many reasons why people have missed out on grants, the principal one being misunderstanding. The provision empowering the surviving partner to apply money saved by the deceased partner, provided it is bequested to the applicant, is worth while indeed. Another provision will make it possible for a young couple to obtain a grant to build a home on a farm owned by parents or other members of the family, where they will not have full ownership of the home and the land, provided they will have sole occupancy of the dwelling. This class of person was formerly ineligible for the grant. This, too, will help many people. The raising of the sum of money that may be saved each year to qualify for the grant is a sensible provision indeed. Very seldom does a couple or an individual save the actual amount prescribed, and perhaps people could miss out under the old conditions. I have set out the main provisions of the Bill. I do not intend to canvass the Act as I think its success has been beyond doubt. I commend the Minister and officers of his Department for their obvious sympathetic consideration for applicants. I support the Bill.

talk.start.para: - First, I congratulate the honourable member for Griffith (Mr Donald Cameron) on his maiden speech tonight. Everybody is glad to get his maiden speech over and done with. It is an ordeal to get up in the National Parliament and make one's first speech, although the absence of interjections may make it a little easier. From now oh, I suppose the honourable member will have to put up with the same sort of treatment as all other members of Parliament have to take from the opposite side. I do not know whether the honourable member will be here for a long time, as one of his colleagues seeks to imply by way of interjection. He may not be here after the next election. At any rate, I congratulate him on his maiden speech this evening.

speech.para: In common with my colleagues on this side, I support the Bill. We support any legislation that will encourage young people to build homes. We feel that any finance they can get from the Government, or any source at all, is of great assistance to them in building their homes. The position of an applicant for a grant under this measure reminds me of that of a fisherman at Norfolk Island who throws in his line and catches a big fish. By the time the fisherman has brought the fish to the side of the boat, all that is left of it is the head. In home building, a little finance is undoubtedly helpful, but by the time the sharks get hold of it there is not much left. The prospective home owner is in financial straits after paying solicitor's fees and stamp duty and buying a little furniture.

The amendments to the homes savings grant legislation have been designed to overcome anomalies, and I commend the Government for extending to widows the opportunity to qualify for this grant. When this legislation was last before the House, during the life of another Parliament, the former member for Hughes moved an amendment along similar lines to an amendment contained in this measure. As most honourable members know, the Hughes electorate, one of the biggest in the Sydney metropolitan area, is a rapidly growing district on the outskirts of Sydney, with intense housing development, and its former representative in this Parliament took a keen interest in housing. On that occasion the Government refused to accept his amendment, but now it intends to extend this assistance to widows.

Many other anomalies in the legislation ought to be eliminated. One is the age barrier, which is a grave injustice to many people. Commonwealth public servants, people of position and standing in the community travel around the country from position to position before being stationed permanently in a city or town, and by this time, being over thirty-six years of age, they cannot qualify for the homes savings grant. The Government should at the very least look after its own employees and see that they obtain a grant. Teachers, other essential workers in the community, are in the same category. They have to travel to different schools throughout the State in their work of educating the children. When the finally settle down in a position they are debarred, through age, from receiving the $500 granted by the Government. Police and firemen are in a similar plight. I feel that these people should be eligible for assistance regardless of age. Indeed, all persons seeking to build their first home should, regardless of age, be eligible for a homes savings grant provided they comply with other requirements of the legislation.

The Minister should have another look at the measure with a view to affording assistance to the people I have mentioned. Other sections of the community are denied this grant, including people who purchase homes from the War Service Homes Division. Other people, who cannot raise enough money to qualify for the grant, have to depend on the Housing Commission. They are denied the $500 that is granted by the Government to other lucky people. Persons in the lower income bracket, striving to get a home together for their wife and family, ought to be encouraged and assisted to buy their own home. The Government should assist these people, who are just as important as other sections of the community. Young conscripts sent by the Government to Vietnam, if fortunate enough to return to Australia, are eligible for a war service home, but they are denied the right to the $500 subsidy to purchase a home. Is this right? Should the Government exclude these young men whom it sends overseas to fight? The Government is denying them this $500 grant, though it sends them overseas. This is a denial of natural justice. The Government should have another look at this situation. These young fellows who have been sent to fight in Vietnam should be entitled, on their return, to this grant of $500 if they wish to purchase a home through the War Service Homes Division.

I wish to refer also to a matter which I have raised previously in the Parliament, and upon which the Minister, of course, has not acted. I refer to the young fellow who builds his own home. He spends all his week-ends and his spare time on this activity because at today's high costs he cannot afford to pay a builder. All the Government will allow a young chap in these circumstances is the lousy builder's fee, which is 10%. If one has to pay someone to build a home for him he will find that this will take at least one-third of his total outlay. The 10% builder's fee, which is what this Government allows a young fellow who builds his own home, represents the profit which the builder makes after he has paid for all the work done on the cottage or home unit or whatever the dwelling may be, and this is all that the Government will allow the young owner-builder who is trying to build his home as cheaply as possible. This is a matter that I believe the Government should again consider carefully, and a young fellow building a home in these circumstances should be allowed at least a third of the valuation of the premises. The Minister is not in the House at present, but I urge him in any case to show these people some more appropriate consideration.

The Government has once again refused to recognise credit unions. This is a matter that has been repeatedly raised in this House, but the Government has always declined to accept, for purposes of legislation of this nature, money invested with credit unions. These organisations encourage people to save. People take money from their wages each week and invest it with credit unions because they know that these unions give them a fair go and offer loans at interest rates that are much more favourable than those available from lending institutions or even from banks. The fact is, however, that money invested with credit unions is not recognised by the Government for the purposes of this kind of legislation. This is a form of discrimination and I believe it is being practised as a result of pressure brought to bear on the Government by financial institutions who realise that credit unions are moving into their field, lending money at low interest' rates and assisting many people to make extensions to homes. Some of these unions are lending up to $4,000 to assist people with second mortgages, and they are levying interest at rates lower than those imposed by the financial institutions. But people who put their money into credit unions cannot have that money recognised for the purpose of receiving homes savings grants. This is an injustice and I believe the Government should change its mind and decide to accept money invested in this way as qualifying for these grants.

Under the existing legislation persons who invest their money in Commonwealth bonds and securities may not receive this benefit because the money is not in a special account. We are supposed to be involved in a war, and a person might feel like putting a few dollars into Commonwealth bonds to assist our war effort. But the Government will not recognise money invested in that way for the purposes of this legislation. How can we encourage people to invest in these bonds if we do not recognise those investments when applications are made for these grants? These are matters that the Government should look at if it really wants to provide money in this way for more people in the community.

The homes savings grants assist many people but still today the supply of homes is lagging behind the demand for them. Our population is increasing, naturally and by migration, and the supply of homes is not keeping pace with the increasing demand. It is rather like a dog chasing its tail. In New South Wales young people are finding it very hard to get a home. Many young people in the low income bracket look to the State Housing Commission to supply a home, but last year the Commission completed only 5,390 homes. This year 29,000 people are on the waiting list of whom about 16,000 were added last year. The Housing Commission caters for people in the low income bracket, but if they obtain a home through the Commission they are not eligible for assistance under this legislation.

The shortage of housing in Australia today is acute. It is about time the Commonwealth Government did something to provide homes for the young people and others who really need them. It should take the initiative by instituting an inquiry into housing to be conducted by representatives of all sections of the community, including members of the building industry and finance corporations. Such an inquiry could discover the real needs in the housing field and the methods necessary to overcome the housing lag. I do not think it is good enough to ask somebody in Melbourne or Brisbane to conduct an inquiry. I do not think the Commonwealth Government should depend on any State body to inquire into housing needs. The initiative should be taken by the Commonwealth Government.

The main requirement of the building industry today is planning. Many building companies are planning for the future but I believe that the real solution can be found by bringing together the specialists in the industry to plan a crash housing programme under the control of the Commonwealth Government. Finance could be made available to builders at low interest rates for them to build satellite towns on the outskirts of the major cities. In the United States of America government money is lent to builders at low interest rates to buy land and materials for the construction of homes. The builders are required to pass on the benefit of the low interest rates to purchasers of the homes. Similar action could be taken by the Commonwealth Government. It controls the purse strings of the country and could offer incentives to private investors, such as special depreciation allowances over a period of years in respect of both land development and home building.

Insurance companies and financial institutions should be encouraged to channel finance into home building instead of the big city office blocks that they are investing in at present. Many of these buildings which have been completed for three years or so still contain empty offices because there is not sufficient demand to fill them. People do not want big city office blocks. The rents are too high and the demand is not sufficient to justify their construction. But these projects are proceeding. A Sydney insurance company is planning to pull down a building in Martin Place. To me it looks to be a building that could stand there for another fifty or sixty years without any trouble. But the insurance company that owns it will pull it down in order to erect a brand new building. Why does the company want to erect a new building when the existing building seems to be in such good order? Either it wants to put on a good show or it has too much money and wants to get rid of some of it. Apparently the only way it knows to get rid of its money is to spend millions of dollars on a new building. This money should be channelled into the erection of homes for those people who are greatly in need of them. The Government could, and should, do something to see that this is done.

Tax incentives should be given to the manufacturers of, for example, prime cost items, which are used in every home. These are ways in which the Government can assist home seekers. We know that labour costs are continuing to soar. Last year there was an increase of 3.15% in the cost of timber homes and of 2.87% in the cost of brick veneer homes. In its annual report the New South Wales Housing Commission stated that tender prices increased by 8% in 1963-64 and by 15% in 1964-65. Prices are increasing all the time because builders have to borrow money at high rates of interest. The builder sometimes has to pay 12% fiat. That cost must be passed on to somebody. It can be passed on only to the ultimate purchaser of the home. It is the purchaser of the home who pays the high rate of interest finally, not the builder. Perhaps this is one reason why today so many home units remain unsold. Another reason may be that the builder, quite apart from wanting to pass on the high interest rates, wants to make a large profit. We know that there is a greater margin of profit for builders in home units than there is in cottages. Many home units are vacant today because they are too dear and because the terms upon which loans are made available for their purchase are too short. Young people cannot afford the weekly repayments demanded for home units. We should do something to assist the builder. We could enable him to borrow at low rates of interest, but we would need to ensure that he passes on the low rates of interest to the purchaser.

We have heard some honourable members opposite express concern at the Government's Intention to provide flats for migrants. Some honourable members oppositehave asked questions in the House seeking to ascertain whether the Government will consider purchasing for this purpose some of the home units that so far cannot be sold. Why do they ask these questions? It is because the people who have built the home units are now left holding the bag and want the Government to take the units off their hands. I do not think the Government should assist these people. It should not purchase these home units simply to assist people who have invested in them and who want a high return for their investment. The Government should at least look around and buy cheap dwelling units rather than take over those home units that remain unsold because they are too costly.

When we consider providing assistance for people seeking a home we should have regard to what happens in other countries. A very good scheme operates in New Zealand, our near neighbour. There the Government, recognising that many people want a home, has done something about supplying money at a low rate of interest. In New Zealand people wishing to purchase a home can borrow money from the Government at an interest rate of 3%. I feel that this Government ought to establish a lending institution through the Commonwealth Bank which could lend money at low rates of interest so that we can assist persons in the low income bracket to borrow enough money with which to build a home. I know that at the last general election the Australian Labor Party put a pretty good housing policy before the Australian people. Unfortunately I do not think that a great many people read it otherwise they would have supported the Labor Party a great deal more. I think that they are very sorry now that they see that they will not get a fair go from this Government. I would say that when the next Budget is introduced it will contain increased charges which will result in soaring costs in home building again, and the grant of £250, which 1 feel has been absorbed at the present time in increased land costs and builders' fees, will be only a little drop in the ocean.

Therefore I feel that we should at least try to do something through the Government to see whether we cannot assist many more people to borrow money. We support the Bill. I have pointed out a few anomalies which 1 feel exist in it. I do not know when we will see a similar Bill to this one again. Probably it will be in the sweet by and by. 1 think that the Minister at least ought to have a look at some of the anomalies that have been raised by members of the Opposition and by Government supporters and try to do something to overcome them and to encourage more people to purchase homes. I conclude on those remarks. I am disappointed with some of the amendments that the Government has introduced. 1 feel that there is still a lot to be done, so far as home building in this community is concerned. I believe that until there is a change of Government and we get a Government that is prepared to take the initiative and to have a look at some long range plans, then there will be a great many people in the community who will be denied a decent home. They will have to live under their present conditions for many years to come.

talker.role: Minister for Labour and National Service
talker.name: BURY, Leslie
Mr BURY

talk.start.para: - in reply - The suggestions which have been made in the course of this debate will be carefully examined by my colleague, in another place, the Minister for Housing (Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin). She will certainly give them due consideration. A number of points have been made in this debate. Without canvassing them all, I should point, first of all, to the remarks of the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Connor). At various times, both in this debate and in others, he has stressed the question of interest rates. At various times he has compared a number of interest rates in other spheres and then compared them with lending rates for housing in Australia, but that is really not comparing like with like. I think that when considered broadly, this is either misleading and mischievous, or stupid, and that is not something that I would accuse the honourable member for Cunningham of being. He is very hard working. He goes into these matters in great detail. He would not have done this unwittingly.

speech.para: In dealing with interest rates, we can take those of the credit unions themselves. I do not want to suggest in any way that the Government is not highly favourably disposed towards credit unions, despite what has been said by honourable members opposite. I have been a member of a credit union, although not in this country. I have great regard for this development which I suppose has spread further in the United States of America than anywhere else. Savings in credit unions are not excluded from the scheme because the unions are not in themselves extremely valuable institutions. They encourage saving in many quarters where saving might not otherwise be undertaken, but they are not directly concerned with the provision of long term finance for houses. One basis of the homes savings grant scheme is that we should encourage saving in the directions that do provide long term finance for housing, either in land or in the institutions that are themselves long term lenders for housing.

If we are to talk about interest rates we could consider those of credit unions. I do not by any means criticise the interest rates, which are realistically adjusted to the position that the unions occupy in the financial system. In New South Wales the flat rate of interest for loans varies between 5% and 6% per annum. If these rates were expressed on the basis of a reducing balance, which would be necessary if the operation were considered in relation to housing, they would range from 9% to 12% per annum. This Ls not to criticise the credit unions, because their rates of interest are sensible in relation to the type of operation in which they engage. They must offer their members quite high rates for deposits and much of their lending involves a measure of risk. However, they play a valuable role in providing loans for many of their members who would otherwise be forced to enter the hire purchase market. This is to be commended. When I held responsibility for this portfolio, I hoped, and I still do, that they would approach the various State governments, which I am sure are on the whole favourably disposed to them, to allow them when necessary the opportunity to form building societies and so increase the amount of long term first mortgage housing finance that is available. If they establish such sections, as I am sure they can and will in the course of time, through which they will provide this kind of long term finance, this eligibility would come up again for consideration.

The honourable member for Bonython (Mr Nicholls) mentioned a number of matters. He pointed particularly to the rather low rate at which homes savings grants have been provided this year as compared with last year. He gave a figure of, I think, $9.69m. It has now risen to $12. lm. I believe the figure last year was in the region of $ 13.3m. It is difficult to compare like with like in this sort of activity, because some amendments have been made. The amendments that are now going through the House will undoubtedly increase the amount disbursed during the

Test of this financial year. The honourable member proposed also that tribunals should be set up to hear appeals against the rejection of applications by the Secretary of the Department, who will have new discretions under this legislation. He suggested that the new provision meant an appeal from Caesar to Caesar, but representations can always be made to the Minister. There are in this House a large number of members who take a very active interest in their constituents. Whatever is said about the advisability of having an ombudsman, I believe that the members of this House by and large perform much better than any ombudsman would the kind of function that is implicit in the suggestion of the honourable member for Bonython. The scheme has grown and been improved as a result of experience gained from cases put to the Department by honourable members. It has been adapted to meet practical changes in circumstances, in fact I think it was the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Hansen) who noted that it has been adjusted as experience has been gained following representations by members from both sides of the House.

The honourable member for East Sydney (Mr Devine) said that the grant should be available to servicemen who return from Vietnam and acquire war service homes. This entitlement is already available to them on the usual basis.

A number of useful suggestions have been made. The honourable member for Maribrynong (Mr Stokes) advanced a suggestion in relation to immigrants. This will certainly be referred to the Minister for Housing in another place with the proviso that the Government is not prepared to favour immigrants or any other section of the community over and above existing inhabitants of Australia. Subject to that, the honourable member's suggestion will be examined together with all the other proposals which have been made in the course of the debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.
