talker.name: BURY, Leslie
Mr BURY

talk.start.para: - The amendment ensures that residents of Nauru who intend at some time in the future to buy or build a home in Australia will have the same opportunities as do residents of other external territories to comply with the savings requirements of the Act. At present the Commonwealth Bank is the only bank represented in Nauru. It will bc appreciated that the population is small and I presume there would be no basis for extending facilities beyond that.
- Does this apply only to banks based within Australia and whose funds would be available for housing within Australia?
- It applies only to the construction of houses in Australia. This is of interest to inhabitants.

speech.para: Clause agreed to.
Clauses 7 to 10 - by leave - taken together.

talk.start.para: - I move:

speech.para: I do so as a direction to the Government that it should recognise savings in credit unions as acceptable savings as from 3.1 st December 1964. We do not disagree with the provisions of clause 7 relating to widows. We note with approval that with an appropriate alteration in dates the savings of widows or their spouses in credit unions will qualify for a grant under the terms of this legislation. The Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr Bury) has stated that he is highly favourably disposed to credit unions and we propose to give him the opportunity to prove this, because we intend to divide the Committee on this motion.

The Minister referred to interest rates. It should be said that whilst the 5% to 6% flat rate which is charged by credit unions can be from 10% to 12% reducing, depending upon the terms and the methods of repayment, at the same time credit unions discharge most valuable functions. As a matter of fact, bridging finance today is still being charged at the rate of 10% flat by most of the hire-purchase institutions and this generally works out at about I9i% or 191% on a reducible basis. I point out that credit unions have a total membership in Australia of 200,000, and I am authorised by the president of the credit unions, which have now formed their own union, to state that they intend to press to the limit this question of recognition which this Government is determined not to grant. They have already amassed some S80m in deposits.

A question has been raised regarding the contribution that credit unions are prepared to make for housing purposes. I quoted figures which have not been contradicted. They are official figures from Mr Arneil. Altogether. 30% of their present funds has been advanced for housing, the purposes in particular being the discharge of second mortgages, assisting in the purchase of land, alterations and extensions to existing homes, bridging finance, and also first mortgage advances up to a seven-year limit. It is correct Co apply the old adage to this case: 'Which comes first, the chicken or the egg?" Why not recognise the credit unions and give them a chance to progress still further with mortgage assistance which they can undoubtedly give to home purchasers?

When the former Prime Minister made his promise of homes savings grants in J 963, no reference whatever was made to the Government's present policy that credit union savings are not acceptable because they make no contribution at all to home savings. That policy was adopted after the 1963 election. Again, when we get down to questions of pure logic, the Government is still persisting - and we do not disagree with it - in recognising contributions that are made by way of instalments and deposits on a contract for the purchase of land as being acceptable savings. Does the Minister or the Government suggest that savings of this nature make a contribution towards funds available for housing? Is it suggested that the average speculator or subdivider who sells land, and of whose activities we do not altogether disapprove, will carefully channel this money into his account for the purpose of lending it out again for housing? I think this is stretching the credulity of members of this Parliament to the very limit. While the Government persists with that, it has no case in logic, in reason, or in decency to deny recognition to the credit union movement.

I have a letter dated 4th April 1967 from Dame Annabelle Rankin, addressed to Mr Arneil, President of the Australian Federation of Credit Union Leagues. She literally but politely slammed the door in their faces and again raised the contention of the Government that savings in credit unions make no contribution whatever to housing. The hard truth - I mentioned this in my speech last night and I have yet to hear any contradiction from the Minister - is that whilst the credit unions have advanced 30% of their funds for housing purposes of the nature I have indicated, even the Commonwealth Savings Bank itself has advanced only 24.1% of its funds for housing purposes. These figures were given to me less than a month ago. Percentage wise, the credit unions are in fact making a greater contribution to housing than is the major, the senior, savings bank in Australia. This is a fact that the Government, of course, will not take into account because its mind and its heart are closed on this particular issue. It is one for which the Government will have to answer to these 200,000 people. In my own electorate, the steel works of the Australian Iron and Steel Pty Ltd at Port Kembla has a credit union with 7,000 members. Most of them are borrowers, of course, but there are some depositors as well. Deposits amount to $1.4m. Are these people on low wages to be denied the right, through their savings, to qualify under the terms of this legislation?

Let us take the case of the Commonwealth Bank itself. The Commonwealth Bank officers have a major credit union. They see the advantage of it and they are men who are trained in the principles of banking. The Australian National University in Canberra has a credit union. There are 9,000 members in the Commonwealth Bank officers credit union. The General Bank Officers Association, comprising officers of the private trading banks, also is In the process of forming a credit union. In the Australian Broadcasting Commission there are 4,000 members in six associations. In most of the sections of the Taxation Branch throughout Australia credit unions have been formed. It was most interesting to hear the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Stokes) refer last night to recognition of savings accumulated overseas by a migrant over a period of two years, brought here and deposited in a bank for one year. He asked for those savings to be recognised as part of savings for this purpose. Are migrants who are members of credit unions at the Port Kembla steel works to be denied a similar right in respect of their savings which have been made over a period of three years in this country? Where is the justice, the logic and the sense in that?

I pay a particular tribute to the work of Mr Arneil. He is a dedicated Australian who has come right up from the grass roots. All the way, heart and soul, he has fought for credit unions and co-operatives. These are registered co-operative societies -something about which the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Country Party agree. We have yet to hear from members of the Country Party of their support in this matter. Members of the Country Party in particular are heavily organised into co-operative societies. Credit unions in New South Wales are registered under the Co-operation Community Settlement and Credit Act. I do not want to delay the Committee unduly but I do press for the clause to be postponed. We consider that this proposal must be put to the test, that Government supporters should stand and be counted, and that members of credit unions in Australia should see the people who are not prepared to grant them recognition.

talk.start.para: - I cannot agree at all with what has been said by the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Connor). I think he is beating the air with his proposals for credit unions. I am disturbed that there is such pathetic ignorance of the real factors associated with housing. It must be remembered that there are two purposes in the assistance given to young people. The first is to encourage young people - girls and boys - from an early age to save for a specific purpose - the ownership of their own homes when they get married. Secondly, it is intended to encourage home ownership which is so beneficial to Australia as a nation. While credit unions are good, they have not been established for the specific purpose of encouraging home ownership. Their purpose is to make credit facilities available for a wide variety of things. I do not discredit credit unions, but the outstanding vehicle by which finance should be made available for home ownership is the per manent building societies, which have been mentioned here tonight. It is interesting, in considering this legislation, to have regard to the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation. Honourable members should note that the major supporter of this corporation is the permanent building societies. As a matter of fact it would be a complete failure without the loans that are insured for the permanent building societies.

speech.para: Why do honourable members want to confuse the issue by recognising a very worthy organisation - credit unions - when we have registered the permanent building societies and, indeed, terminating building societies, in both of which young people should be encouraged to deposit savings for the specific purpose for which this legislation is intended? It is all very well to talk as the honourable member for Cunningham talked. I paid close attention to his speech and I would expand on some of his comments had I the opportunity to do so, but they were not pertinent to the clause we are considering. The Government intends no discredit in not recognising credit unions, but such recognition would confuse the issue and it would not encourage young people to save for home ownership.

If the Government wants to solve the housing problem and wants to encourage a greater degree of home ownership the cheapest and most effective way would be by allowing taxation concessions on deposits in permanent building societies which are developing extensively in Australia and which will extend further if the States use them as the principle vehicle for financing home ownership. I hope 'that the Government will consider the suggestions concerning permanent building societies, particularly that regarding taxation relief on depositors' savings and investors' shares in such societies. This will make money available to people at low rates of interest and will encourage young people to save. It will meet all the points that the honourable member for Cunningham and other members of the Opposition have advocated in relation to the recognition of credit unions. I have nothing against credit unions; but in my opinion they are not the right vehicle to recognise for this purpose. Therefore, I will not agree that they should be recognised under this legislation.

talk.start.para: - I support the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Connor). I believe that, with the growth of credit unions, they should be accepted by the Government for this purpose. In refusing to recognise money that has been invested in credit unions as acceptable savings, the Government is doing an injustice to the 200,000 people who are putting their money into them. The main point about which we in this country should be concerned is that young people should be prepared to save. It does not matter whether they save in credit unions, in special bank accounts, in Commonwealth bonds or in the permanent building societies that were mentioned by the honourable member for Bennelong (Sh John Cramer). If people save money, when they wish to purchase a home that money should be recognised by the Government as acceptable savings, no matter where it is saved.

speech.para: In my opinion, credit unions are playing a very important part in the community today by encouraging young people to save money. There is no doubt that people gel a better go from credit unions than from the banks, the permanent building societies or other institutions in which they may invest money. If a young person wants to put his money into a credit union, we should encourage him to do so by recognising credit unions for the purpose of home savings grants. Over the years in which we have raised this matter in this chamber, the Government has always said that it will not accept the credit unions. I do not know why it will not accept them. I do not think it has ever given the people of Australia or the credit unions a decent, sound reason why it has refused to accept them.

The credit unions are growing. Their members are becoming a big section of the community. Every year more people are taking an interest in them. These people know that they will get a better go from credit unions. They know that they will be able to borrow money at a decent rate of interest in order to buy goods that they require. That is why I believe that the credit unions should be encouraged and assisted by the Government. If the Government sincerely believes that people wishing to own their own homes should be assisted, it should go out of its way to assist these institutions. But it will not accept them for this purpose.

I honestly believe that the reason why it will not accept them is that they have entered the field of the financial institutions which are bleeding money out of the young people of this community by charging exorbitant rates of interest. At the present time the credit unions are in opposition to the financial institutions that support the Government. Pressure is being applied to the Government by insurance companies and other financial institutions. They do not want the Government to accept credit unions for this purpose. The credit unions are establishing their own insurance companies with the support of the headquarters of the movement in America. The Americans recognise that because of the growth that credit unions are making in Australia at the present time they should be supported, and they are doing that. I believe that we should do that too.

We should say to people: 'If you put your money into a credit union and are prepared to save in order to own a home, we will accept those savings', lt does not matter whether a person puts his money into a credit union, a motor car or a block of land; he is still saving. If he saves money and then wants to buy his own home, the Government should accept that money as savings. In my opinion, credit unions are growing because they consist of a great number of people who band together to save their money for a common purpose.

Probably the Government is opposed to credit unions because it believes they may be associated with socialisation. They are organisations in which a number of people have joined together in harmony and have bonded their money so that others may benefit at a fair rate of interest. I have advocated this in the Parliament, and I have heard even members of the Government advocate it. We have to do something about the present high rates of interest, and if we do not assist credit unions, how will people get a fair go when they seek to put an extra room on their house, or to put on a new roof or effect renovations? Credit unions are doing something for the community by assisting people with their housing difficulties. Therefore, it is up to the
Government to assist any of these worthy institutions that are willing to assist young people in this respect.

The Government has been pigheaded in its refusal to accept credit unions, apparently in the belief that it should refuse them because Labor has put up the proposition. The Government cannot see past its nose. It fails to appreciate that credit unions are developing and will be significant organisations in future. Why does the Government not accept the money of the young people who are willing to pay into credit unions? If the Government wishes to assist young people and is sincere about it, why does it not say: 'Very well, the money that you invest in a credit union will be accepted for the purposes of this legislation, and you will receive the $500'? In this way the people who have saved their money will benefit a great deal. Credit unions are here to stay, and they will be here when we go. Having in mind their growth and the way they are going, the Government will have to recognise them in future, whether it likes it or not. The Government should knock the chip off its shoulder and realise that it is about time credit unions were recognised. Indeed, it has been hard enough to get members of this Government to recognise the trade unions.

I support the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Connor), for I believe that this is a sincere move for a postponement. The Government should examine this matter and at least should accept the credit unions and recognise the money invested in them as money that comes within the provisions of this legislation.

talk.start.para: - I did not intend to speak until I heard a couple of the points that have been mentioned. The honourable member for Bennelong (Sir John Cramer) mentioned that credit unions dealt with savings for specific purposes and that money could be drawn out by the members at any time. But money can be withdrawn at any time from a home savings account and used for the purchase of any article at all. The money need not be used solely for the purpose of purchasing a home. The honourable member pointed out also that one of the main purposes of the principal Act is to encourage young people to save - from a tender age, I think he said. One of the best ways for people to save is to commence from their first pay envelope. Although it may be too early at that stage for them to be thinking about purchasing a home, and their thoughts may be much closer to a motor car, at least they are encouraged to save in credit unions by the people with whom they associate and work from day to day, for credit unions are formed by people who have daily or regular contact with each other, generally at their place of employment.

speech.para: In his reply to the second reading debate the Minister promised to look into the matter raised by the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Stokes), who suggested that migrants be given some credit for the savings they had made prior to their arrival in Australia. If this is permitted, people who saved money while they were living outside of Australia would derive some benefit although their savings had not been used for the construction of bornes in Australia. If savings in credit unions are not accepted, the Government will deny the same concession to Australians^ - some of them widowed - who had been saving their money for years in credit unions. I do not see how migrants could receive this concession while credit unions were not recognised. I point out also that the credit union movement has taken up the challenge which was issued by the Minister when he was Minister for Housing and has ensured that some of its funds are available for housing.

As has been mentioned, credit unions have made small loans for some time to bridge the deposit gap, but at least two credit unions in New South Wales - the Electricity Commission Employees Credit Union and Irrigation Commission Credit Union - have taken up the challenge and are making available loans up to a maximum of $4,000. These loans are for the specific purpose of housing. So I believe that credit unions are endeavouring to meet the challenge which was issued by the Minister on that occasion. I mention these matters because they have not been mentioned by previous speakers. For all these reasons, and for reasons stated on other occasions, I believe that the Minister should consider the situation of credit unions and once again make representations to the
Minister for Housing to have them included in the legislation as eligible organisations.

talker.role: Minister for Labour and National Service
talker.name: BURY, Leslie
Mr BURY

talk.start.para: - I propose to deal briefly with some of the points which have been made. I refer, first, to the remarks made by the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Connor), lt was made quite clear in the 1963 election policy speech that savings for the purpose of this measure would be those in designated accounts. Subsequently, investment in land was added as another form of eligible savings. This has been maintained throughout. Booklets have been published to explain the provisions of the Act, so anyone who set out consciously to save for a home has known, almost ever since that date, where he would have to place his savings.

speech.para: I refer next to remarks made about the co-operative movement. This type of institution is one that I believe we would all like to foster. The form of co-operative saving for the construction and purchase of housing is through the co-operative housing societies, lt has always been our hope that the credit unions would adapt thenactivities, as I am sure they will increasingly in future, to include such operations, in which case they would attract eligibility for the grant. I share with the honourable member for Cunningham his regard for Mr Arneil, who is a most zealous and devoted man in the promotion of credit unions. However, to say that credit unions are not suitable vehicles at the moment for the purchase and construction of houses is just to state a fact. It could be true, as the honourable member for Cunningham said, that 40%, or probably nearer 30%, of their loans do go into some aspect of housing, and most of that expenditure would be for things such as repairs, for the purchase of furniture and equipment of various kinds or for second mortgages. That is true enough, but they are not housing loans in the true sense. If the credit unions adapt themselves to provide first mortgage housing money for the construction and purchase of homes they will attract the grant, but this is not the case at present.

The honourable member for East Sydney (Mr Devine) went much further and said that all savings should attract the grant and this would alter the basis of the scheme. It is not only private financial institutions which are involved. The major institution involved in this process is a public institution, that is, the Commonwealth Savings Bank. It is quite the largest single institution in this field and savings deposited with it are fully eligible. I do deplore the suggestion that, because one says that credit unions do not provide for savings for this specific purpose, that this means denigrating credit unions at large which do fulfil a very valuable if different purpose. As the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Hansen) has said, they provide for a form of saving. It may be saving for a motor car or for all sorts of other things. This is highly desirable and I think it is to be encouraged; but if we want to get more houses built we should encourage people to put their savings into institutions which provide first mortgage finance for the construction of houses. If we were to widen the scheme so that all forms of savings become eligible, we would have a different scheme. We have rejected, for instance, Government bonds and all kinds of other things, saving for which, although highly desirable and to be encouraged in every way, does not provide first mortgage money for housing loans - the Government's prime objective.

talk.start.para: - 1 move -

quote.para: That the clause be postponed.

speech.para: I propose this motion as an instruction to the Government to devise a better means of assessing the value of homes in respect of which claims for grants are lodged. Probably every honourable member has received complaints from time to time from dissatisfied constituents who have been told that, in the opinion of the Secretary of the Department or one of his delegates, the value of their home was in excess of the limit prescribed by the Act. We do not object to the increase of the valuation limit from $14,000 to $15,000. In the case of New South Wales it does more than offset the increase of $1,062 which has been proved in the report of the War Service Homes Division to be the increase in the cost of erecting a home in the two years from 1964 to 1966.

The Opposition believes that this section of the Act is being used as an escape hatch by the Government. I do not suggest any malpractice on the part of the officers of the Department of Housing. But when a discretion of mis nature is provided in an Act, naturally the officer administering it will play safe. But we do say this: Statutory authorities are available in each of the States throughout Australia without exception - valuers under the various enactments of the State legislatures - any one of whom could be called on to arbitrate by a dissatisfied applicant. At the present time, the utmost that can be done when any member receives a complaint from a rejected applicant is to ask for the matter to be reconsidered and further facts to be pointed out. But the answer that invariably comes back is that the officer is 'adhering to his previous decision. In fairness, in a case like this, it is a matter of bitter disappointment to many people and particularly to people who have been frugal enough and energetic enough to make a contribution in terms of labour towards the construction of their own homes. These people in particular are most dissatisfied with the assessment that is being made in many cases.

As I have said, statutory authorities are available in each of the States. There is a Valuer-General in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland. In Tasmania there is a valuation branch of the Premier's Department. Valuations are made in Western Australia for local government by the Taxation Department. There is no reason at all why, if there is goodwill on the part of the Government, some method should not be devised whereby the statutory authority operating in any particular State could not be called in as a final court of appeal without the necessity for complicated proceedings. A very simple amendment to the Act could be introduced for this purpose. But the Government does not intend to do that because this section is an escape hatch for the Government.

The scheme is running into a higher cost than ever the Government imagined. The Government realises that somewhere along the line economies have to be made. Whilst the Government has grudgingly granted an increase from $14,000 to $15,000 in the permissible value of a borne for the purpose of attracting the grant it certainly intends to use every possible means when the value of the applicant's property approaches the limit to see that his application is rejected. I have a classical illustration of this in relation to a constituent of mine who is an electrician. He and his wife are a worthy young couple. I have here an itemised list of the total cost of construction of a very nice home. This application was made in 1966. The cost of the home was $8,999.83. The cost of the land was another §1,300. The application was rejected. We asked for a review with the inevitable second refusal. In cases like this - I have no doubt that other honourable members on the Opposition side who will speak on this matter will draw attention to similar cases - where there is acute dissatisfaction there is, as the honourable member for Bonython (Mr Nicholls) put it, literally an appeal from Caesar to Caesar. With goodwill on the part of the Government, the good offices of the valuergeneral or his counterpart in the States concerned could be invoked and a decision readily given. Valuation rolls are available in each State. His decision, I am sure, would be an acceptable one that would vindicate the judgment of the officer of the Department of Housing whose valuation was being challenged. At the same time, satisfaction would be given to the rejected applicant.

talker.role: Minister for Labour and National Service
talker.name: BURY, Leslie
Mr BURY

talk.start.para: - I wish to make clear that this scheme is not administered in such a way as to reduce deliberately the grants paid to applicants to save public money. In most cases any reasonable doubt works in the other direction. The value placed on homes by other authorities, particularly the Valuer-General, is one of the pertinent things taken into account when valuing a house. The valuation is always a matter of opinion, particularly when it is on the borderline and someone has to decide the case, it is certainly not written up deliberately for this purpose. Values are not written up in order to reduce the outlay of the Government. This provision is, however, and has been from the start, a very important protection for public funds.

speech.para: Amendment negatived.

talk.start.para: - I wish to speak to clause 11. I did not vote for the amendment moved by the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr

speech.para: Connor) because this Bill will give an advantage to people and should not be postponed. Furthermore I did not think that what he was saying was terribly practical. It was not focused in any way at all. I want to suggest to the Government two specific things which will make this good Bill better. The first is that where the value of the dwelling is mentioned in clause 11 we should have in its place the words 'the cost or value of the dwelling house, whichever is the lesser*. We want to encourage the man who is doing his own building. We do not want to have the position which has arisen often in my electorate where a man has spent something under the specified amount by using his own labour and, because of this, the house is said to be valued above the specified amount and is therefore ineligible for subsidy. This is a bad thing in practice. Surely when we are talking of saving and industry, and housing the people better, we should be encouraging people who have technical skills in building to use those skills for their own advantage and the advantage of their families.

I hoped to move an amendment in this regard but I am told that under standing order 292 it is not competent for me to do so. This is an extraordinary state of affairs. I understand that the Senate Standing Orders would permit the moving of an amendment of this kind even though financial responsibility is said to reside in this House rather than in the Senate. But it would appear that according to practices current in this House - based on what I believe is an erroneous interpretation of section 56 of the Constitution, an interpretation which is not followed by the Senate - it would be out of order for me to move the amendment I would like to move.

I have had the amendment drafted and I propose to give it to the Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr Bury). I hope it will be taken into consideration. I propose that where the value of a dwelling house is mentioned in lines twenty-five and twenty-six of clause 11 we should insert the cost or value of the dwelling house, whichever is the lesser'. This will not involve much extra expenditure. It will help to achieve the Government's objective which is to get people to make provision for their own housing. If they build their own house themselves, that is just as good as an extra act of saving. Under the Standing Orders it is not practicable for me to move an amendment in these terms, but I suggest that the Government give serious consideration to my suggestion. I am not being diffuse and woolly, as the honourable member for Cunningham was. I am suggesting a specific form of words in a specific place to rectify an anomaly. At the present time the valuer has no option. In making a valuation he must include the value of the work put into the house by the owner. He is under an obligation when valuing some houses built by the owner to put on the property a value that will put it outside the range of the homes savings grant.

It is anomalous that the subsidy should be cut ofl: sharply at the old figure of $14,000 or the new figure of $15,000. I know people in my electorate whose homes were valued at only £2 to £3 over the specified maximum value, and because of that they received no grants. This is a ridiculous anomaly and I do not think the Government means this to occur. The anomaly could be easily cured, but not by putting in a higher ceiling limit which will still result in similar anomalies. Instead, I suggest that the Government adopt a method that has been adopted in many Acts, and provide for a tapering formula. I have prepared a specific formula, but unfortunately, because of a quirk of the Standing Orders, it is not competent for me to move an amendment to this effect. I am not taking refuge in generalities. I have prepared a specific formula that I think should be included at the end of the clause. I suggest the addition of the following proviso:

quote.para: Provided that where such a lesser amount exceeds $15,000, a grant diminished by one half of such excess may nevertheless be made.

speech.para: Acceptance of my suggestion will mean that no grant will be made when the value is over SI 6,000, but when a House is valued between $15,000 and $16,000 there wil be a gradual tapering off of the amount of grant. This principle has been embodied in many Acts. The owner of a house valued at SI 5,0 10 would get the full grant less $5, receiving $495. The amount of 'grant would taper off by one half of the excess. There would be no difficulty in drafting such a provision. It would not involve extra expenditure of any consequence and it would get rid of an awkward anomaly with which I am familiar and of which, I dare say, other honourable members have had experience in their constituencies.

I ask the Government to consider on their merits my two proposals, both of which are meant to be constructive. Neither of them will involve the Government in the expenditure of any great sum of money. If accepted, they will make a good Act just a little better. I have drafted proposed amendments that are quite specific. It is unfortunate that under the Standing Orders I am not pemitted to move them. I now present them to the Minister and ask him whether the Government will consider them and if possible, incorporate them in the measure in another place. If the Minister and the Government so desire, the amendments could be made here tonight.
Friday, 5 May 1967

talk.start.para: -^l will not detain the Committee for very long. The provision in question imposes a limit on the value of a house that can attract the grant of $500. I suppose I have little chance of persuading the Minister this year to do what he would not do last year, but I do ask him to give some consideration to this point: An act which is supposed to confer a benefit on people should confer that benefit equally and evenly throughout the whole of the Commonwealth, and the Minister might have regard to the fact that the costs of building are not the same throughout the length and breadth of the Commonwealth.

speech.para: The honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Connor) has quoted figures giving average costs of homes in the various capitals of the States and in the Australian Capital Territory. I think a more realistic approach for the Minister to adopt would be to take the cost of building per square in the various capital cities and in the inland provincial cities. A home which can be built for $15,000 in Sydney would probably cost $17,000 in this city, and it would seem to me that the Minister and his Department might devise means whereby the differences in costs of building could be taken into account so that in areas of higher costs the ceiling figure could be lifted
In order that all people might be able to benefit evenly from the grant that is made.

I may not be making my point specifically enough for the Minister, but this is a matter that has been discussed previously and I think it is worth consideration. If we seek to provide a benefit we should seek to provide it evenly to all people who come within the ambit of the legislation, and this is not being done when costs of construction are so vastly different as they are in the various parts of this country. I think means could be found of providing a variation in the ceiling limit in consonance with the variations in costs of building in the different areas.

talker.role: Minister for Labour and National Service
talker.name: BURY, Leslie
Mr BURY

talk.start.para: - I think we can all appreciate the point which has been made by the honourable member for the Australian Capital Territory (Mr J. R. Fraser), but I think the honourable member will appreciate that the Commonwealth cannot vary the law to pay varying amounts depending on location in different parts of Australia. Perhaps an equally compelling case might be made on the basis of cost of living variations for differential rates of income tax. The cost of living may be higher in one place than in another and this basis could be a reason for providing for payment of tax at different rates. It may be that the Australian Capital Territory is the dearest place of all for building, and Queensland the cheapest. It is unlikely to be within the constitutional power of the Commonwealth to vary the amounts paid in different places on these grounds. However, I recognise the problem to which the honourable member has directed attention.

speech.para: I will convey the suggestions of the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Wentworth) to the Minister for Housing (Senator Dame Annabelle Rankin) for her consideration. It may interest the House to know that in most cases grants are paid on the basis of cost and not value. This is so in most cases of purchases of existing homes or where homes are constructed by builders. These make up more than 90% of the total. It may also interest the Committee to know that from the start of the scheme until 28th February this year only 707 applications were rejected on grounds of cost out of more than 80,000 applications received.

talk.start.para: - Have it incorporated in Hansard to save time.

- The honourable member might have suggested that a little earlier, before I spoke, if he had had a sense of decorum. The commonest circumstances in which value as distinct from cost is applied are where a person other than the applicant or the spouse has contributed towards the cost - for example the land may have been given to the applicant - where the property is to be used in addition to its use as a home for a purpose such as a doctor's surgery; where a home has been built on farm land; or where a home has been constructed by an applicant as an owner/ builder. I think the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Connor) had the latter case mainly in view. Where the applicant is an owner/ builder it is not possible for the Department to determine with any certainty what the home actually cost. No matter what receipts or other evidence the applicant produces there is no way of establishing that those are records of all the payments made.

speech.para: Owner/ builders set about the project of building their homes in a great variety of ways. A skilled tradesman may do much of the work himself and the cost to him may be less than that to an unskilled owner/ builder who merely takes the place of a builder and sub-contracts ali the work to tradesmen. Between these extremes, the extent of the work performed by an owner/ builder may vary considerably. As these factors make it impossible for the Department to determine the precise cost of a home to an owner/ builder, there is no alternative but to value the home.

Valuations are made by qualified architects or valuers who estimate what the house and improvements would have cost had they been constructed by a building contractor. In making this valuation the builder's normal profit margin of 10% is excluded so that the value of the house and improvements corresponds to the net cost to the builder. The cost of the land to the applicant is then added to arrive at the value of the home for the purposes of the Homes Savings Grant Act. 1 appreciate the point made by the honourable member for Cunningham and other honourable members, but the fact is that from a practical point of view, after exhaustive examination the existing system was found to be the only one which works in practice.

quote.para: What are the (a) dates and (b) texts of the conditions under which successive Ministers have determined that moneys appropriated by Parliament are payable to a State or States pursuant to the Slates Grants (War Service Land Settlement) Act 1952-1953?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The States Grants (War Service Land Settlement) Act received assent on 12th June 1952 and commenced on 10th July 1952. In October 1952, following discussions between Commonwealth and State Ministers responsible for administering the War Service Land Settlement scheme, the Commonwealth Minister for the Interior forwarded to each Slate Minister a Memorandum of conditions for the granting of financial assistance to the State under Section 96 of the Commonwealth Constitution for the conduct of a scheme of war service land settlement.
The conditions in this document were substantially in the form of the schedules to the War Service Land Settlement Agreements Act 1945 according to the States to which those schedules applied.

As the memorandum for each State varies slightly in wording according to the requirements of State legislation and in each case is a document comparable in length to the schedules nf the 1945 Act, it would be unnecessarily repetitive to provide texts. The main points of difference from the schedules to the 1945 Act were the incorporation of eligibility for ex-servicemen from the Korea/Malaya operations and provision was made for allotment on or conversion to tenure other than perpetual leasehold.

State Ministers made representations for slight amendments to the conditions to comply with Stale legislation for the War Service Land Settlement scheme. Following consideration and agreement on these matters, the Conditions were drawn in a more orderly sequence than formerly. Apart from minor alterations mentioned in this paragraph, the conditions in the revised' format were the same as those in the first memorandum of October 1952.

The conditions in the revised form were determined by the Minister for the Interior and forwarded to the individual States on 30th July 1953. These conditions have not been printed. However, the Western Australian legislation - the War Service Land Settlement Scheme Act No. 29 of 1954 - makes reference to the conditions and the Western Australian Government has printed them in the form determined by the Minister for the Interior on 30th July 1953. Apart from minor variations, those conditions as printed apply to South Australia and Tasmania.
The need for two schedules to the original 1945 Act arose from the difference in degree of financial responsibility accepted by the States for the conduct of the War Service Land Settlement scheme.

As a similar position regarding finance has been maintained since inception of the scheme, the conditions applicable to the States of Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria vary from those for the other States, but only in terms of intergovernmental agreements on finance.
Since the conditions were issued on 30th July 1953 there have been three minor amendments.

On 23rd October 1957 the Minister for Primary Industry advised the 'agent' States that die clause relative to period of occupation before conversion to freehold could be exercised, should be liberalised to allow special circumstances to be taken into consideration if a reduction in the time was requested by a settler.
On 31st August 1960 I varied the wording of one of the conditions applying to Tasmania to clarify the States liability to contribute to excess costs.
On 17th October 1963, again to clarify the position in Tasmania, I varied the wording of one clause by inserting 'form of perpetual' as descrip- live of [he lease in that Slate.
